unnormalised: Okay, here's a blog post generated based on your instructions, focusing on humorous coverage of dates and times in news and media.
normalised: **is my watch broken? a humorous look at indian news timelines**

unnormalised: **Is My Watch Broken? A Humorous Look at Indian News Timelines**
normalised: so, i was reading the news the other day, trying to figure out when the world was supposed to end (again), and i realised something profound: time, as reported by indian news outlets, is a truly fluid concept. it's like einstein and chai had a baby and named it "maybe o'clock."

unnormalised: So, I was reading the news the other day, trying to figure out when the world was supposed to end (again), and I realised something profound: time, as reported by Indian news outlets, is a truly fluid concept. It's like Einstein and chai had a baby and named it "Maybe O'Clock."
normalised: first, there's the whole "breaking news" phenomenon. everything is "breaking," even if it happened, like, three hours ago. you’d think the world was perpetually shattering into a million pieces, judging by the headlines. a politician sneezed? breaking! someone actually used their indicator while driving? breaking! my neighbour finally fixed his leaky tap? you guessed it, breaking! i mean, come on.

unnormalised: First, there's the whole "breaking news" phenomenon. Everything is "breaking," even if it happened, like, 3 hours ago. You’d think the world was perpetually shattering into a million pieces, judging by the headlines. A politician sneezed? Breaking! Someone actually used their indicator while driving? Breaking! My neighbour finally fixed his leaky tap? You guessed it, BREAKING! I mean, come on.
normalised: then we get into the specifics. "the incident occurred sometime around tenish p m," one article cheerfully declared. tenish p m? is that plus or minus an hour? a day? a week? are we talking I-S-T (indian standard time), or have we accidentally stumbled into some sort of parallel universe where time zones are determined by the phases of the moon? my guess is as good as yours.

unnormalised: Then we get into the specifics. "The incident occurred sometime around 10ish PM," one article cheerfully declared. 10ish PM? Is that plus or minus an hour? A day? A week? Are we talking IST (Indian Standard Time), or have we accidentally stumbled into some sort of parallel universe where time zones are determined by the phases of the moon? My guess is as good as yours.
normalised: and don't even get me started on deadlines. things are "due on thirtieth june," but will anything actually happen on that date? nah. maybe the paperwork will get filed by, oh, say, seventh july? or maybe it'll get "preponed" (because india loves prepone, as opposed to that boring old “bring forward” thing).

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on deadlines. Things are "due on 30/6," but will anything actually happen on that date? Nah. Maybe the paperwork will get filed by, oh, say, 7/7? Or maybe it'll get "preponed" (because India loves prepone, as opposed to that boring old “bring forward” thing).
normalised: speaking of "preponed," who even invented that word? i swear, it's like we collectively decided to mess with the english language just to see how far we could push it. and we haven't stopped. every other sentence is a delightful mix of british colonial vocabulary and colloquialisms that would make shakespeare weep with confusion.

unnormalised: Speaking of "preponed," who even invented that word? I swear, it's like we collectively decided to mess with the English language just to see how far we could push it. And we haven't stopped. Every other sentence is a delightful mix of British colonial vocabulary and colloquialisms that would make Shakespeare weep with confusion.
normalised: remember when that astrologer predicted the world would end on twelfth december two thousand and twelve? i spent the whole day in my pajamas, eating samosas and waiting for the apocalypse. it never happened. i felt thoroughly conned, until, a week later, another astrologer said the world was actually ending on twenty first december two thousand and twelve. i had to go out and buy more samosas.

unnormalised: Remember when that astrologer predicted the world would end on 12/12/12? I spent the whole day in my pajamas, eating samosas and waiting for the apocalypse. It never happened. I felt thoroughly conned, until, a week later, another astrologer said the world was actually ending on 21/12/12. I had to go out and buy more samosas.
normalised: the lesson here, folks, is simple: take everything you read in the news about dates and times with a massive pinch of salt (or, you know, a whole packet of lays). treat every deadline as a suggestion, every breaking news item as a historical curiosity, and every astrologer's prediction as a comedy routine. your blood pressure (and sanity) will thank you for it.

unnormalised: The lesson here, folks, is simple: take everything you read in the news about dates and times with a massive pinch of salt (or, you know, a whole packet of Lays). Treat every deadline as a suggestion, every breaking news item as a historical curiosity, and every astrologer's prediction as a comedy routine. Your blood pressure (and sanity) will thank you for it.
normalised: so next time you see a headline screaming "important announcement at eleven zero zero a m!" just remember: it probably means sometime between eleven zero zero a m and next tuesday, depending on the mood of the news anchor and whether the chai break has finished. embrace the chaos, my friends. embrace the maybe o'clock.

unnormalised: So next time you see a headline screaming "Important announcement at 11:00 AM!" just remember: it probably means sometime between 11:00 AM and next Tuesday, depending on the mood of the news anchor and whether the chai break has finished. Embrace the chaos, my friends. Embrace the Maybe O'Clock.
